docs.lead_paragraph: In many American neighborhoods, poor eating habits may stem from a lack of access to fresh, nutritious food, new research suggests. The more supermarkets a neighborhood has, the more fruits and vegetables its residents eat, according to a study from the University of North Carolina.

headline.main: Good Health Is Linked To Grocer

docs.abstract: Study from University of North Carolina finds that the more supermarkets a neighborhood has, the more fruits and vegetables its residents eat; effect is especially strong in predominantly black neighborhoods, where produce consumption rose by 32 percent for each additional supermarket; supermarkets are more likely than small groceries to offer wide selection of food at affordable prices; photos (M)
